rev.comment: older versions can also be considered "current" since they are not discontinued yet
rev.diff:
Line 31: Line 31:
Canonical endorses and provides support for three additional Ubuntu-derived operating systems: [[Kubuntu]], [[Edubuntu]] and Ubuntu Server Edition. There are several other derivative operating systems including local language and hardware-specific versions.<ref name="ubuntu_derivatives"/>
Canonical endorses and provides support for three additional Ubuntu-derived operating systems: [[Kubuntu]], [[Edubuntu]] and Ubuntu Server Edition. There are several other derivative operating systems including local language and hardware-specific versions.<ref name="ubuntu_derivatives"/>
â
Canonical releases new versions of Ubuntu every six months and supports Ubuntu for eighteen months by providing security fixes, [[Patch (computing) | patches]] to critical bugs and minor updates to programs. LTS (Long Term Support) versions, which are released every two years,<ref>{{cite web |url = http://www.markshuttleworth.com/archives/146 |authorlink = Mark Shuttleworth |title= Â» Blog Archive Â» The Art of Release |accessdate = 2008-05-13 |last = Shuttleworth |first = Mark }}</ref> are supported for three years on the desktop and five years for servers.<ref>{{cite web |url=http://www.ubuntu.com/news/ubuntu-8.04-lts-desktop |title=Ubuntu 8.04 LTS Desktop Edition Released |publisher=www.ubuntu.com |accessdate=2008-05-13}}</ref> The current version of Ubuntu, ''9.10'' ([[Karmic Koala]]), was released on October 29, 2009.
+
Canonical releases new versions of Ubuntu every six months and supports Ubuntu for eighteen months by providing security fixes, [[Patch (computing) | patches]] to critical bugs and minor updates to programs. LTS (Long Term Support) versions, which are released every two years,<ref>{{cite web |url = http://www.markshuttleworth.com/archives/146 |authorlink = Mark Shuttleworth |title= Â» Blog Archive Â» The Art of Release |accessdate = 2008-05-13 |last = Shuttleworth |first = Mark }}</ref> are supported for three years on the desktop and five years for servers.<ref>{{cite web |url=http://www.ubuntu.com/news/ubuntu-8.04-lts-desktop |title=Ubuntu 8.04 LTS Desktop Edition Released |publisher=www.ubuntu.com |accessdate=2008-05-13}}</ref> The latest version of Ubuntu, ''9.10'' ([[Karmic Koala]]), was released on October 29, 2009.
